Award.AwardTitle: Defect Chemistry of Metal Oxides for Catalytic Reactive Oxygen Species Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program is funding Chin Li Cheung of the University of Nebraska at Lincoln and Wai-Ning Mei of the University of Nebraska at Omaha for research to investigate how certain industrially important catalysts function. The specific focus of this project seeks to understand how defects in tiny metal oxide particles lead to their ability to function as catalysts. One of oxides being studied, a substance known as cerium oxide, is used extensively as a catalyst in automobile catalytic converters, as a key component in petroleum refining, and in a wide variety of chemical manufacturing applications. Despite its widespread use and importance to industry, the mechanism for cerium oxide's catalytic activity is still not well understood. To investigate this in more detail, the group is preparing small particles of cerium oxide with imperfections, or defects, on their surfaces. These small particles are also being prepared in such a way that they contain foreign metals, or dopants, also thought to be related to their catalytic activity. The ability of these carefully prepared particles to catalyze chemical reactions is determined and, then, correlated with the defects and dopants that are present. The group is using computer modeling to more fully understand the reactions that may be taking place during catalysis. With this combined experimental and theoretical approach, the investigators are able to more completely control the catalytic activity of these small particles and more fully understand how they function. The work is having a broad impact on industry and technology, and may lead to improved catalysts for a wide variety of technological applications. The work is having a further broad impact through the engagement of students at both the undergraduate and high school level. Even younger students are being included in the work through an innovative summer camp program for middle school and home-schooled students.

This project aims to develop a fundamental understanding of the role of surface-subsurface defect interactions on the chemical activity of surface binding sites that are involved in molecular adsorption in metal oxide systems of reduced dimension. Such knowledge is expected to yield catalytic pathways for reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and annihilation with reducible metal oxide in the environment and in industrial processes. Ceria nanoparticles with different shapes, facets and chemical impurity content are being synthesized by hydrothermal methods. The kinetics of the catalytic reactions of these particles with hydrogen peroxide to generate ROS are being determined. Analysis of the kinetic data coupled with DFT modeling are used to identify the effect of subsurface defects on the molecular adsorption energies at the surface binding sites and to determine potential molecular reaction pathways.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, Dr. Chin Li Cheung at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) and Dr. Wai-Ning Mei at the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO) were supported to investigate the catalytic generation of reactive oxygen species by transition metal oxide-based nanomaterials and the roles of defect chemistry in these reactions. Reactive oxygen species are an important class of oxygen-containing molecules, ions, and radicals (such as singlet oxygen, superoxide, and hydroxyl radical) in nature. These chemicals play key roles in the regulation of cellular processes in biology and the chemical reactions in the environment. Thus, besides the fundamental understanding of catalysis science, the study has immense potential impacts in understanding the development of diseases and the processes for environmental remediation.

Over the span of this project, the team applied an experiment-theory approach to elucidate reaction mechanisms of how transition metal oxide catalysts decompose hydrogen peroxide to produce reactive oxygen species and evaluate the catalytic activities of catalysts of different structures. The team had developed fluorescence-based methods for evaluating and comparing these oxide catalysts of different structures, compositions, and levels of lattice defects. Our density functional theory and ab initio molecular dynamics modeling provided detailed atomistic descriptions of the chemical mechanisms. Our research results revealed that the rates of these reactions depend on the types of facets (or crystalline surfaces) and shapes of the metal oxide catalysts, density of oxygen vacancy defects (vacancy of oxygen atoms in the lattice of the catalysts), the presence of water on the catalyst surface, the presence of foreign metal dopants in the crystal lattice and reaction conditions such as temperature. For an example, the activity trend of cerium oxide catalysts of different morphologies follows as: activity(nanorods) > activity(nanocubes) > activity(nanooctahedra). The catalytic production of reactive oxygen species from hydrogen peroxides over transition metal oxide catalysts was found to be enabled by electron transfers between the metal ions and the reactants. Our results indicated that low concentration of low-valency metal dopants can increase the density of oxygen vacancy defects and enhance the activity of the metal oxide catalysts. However, too high concentrations of these dopants, though can further increase the defect density, can drastically decrease the catalytic activity of these materials. Furthermore, our results confirmed the involvement of water molecules in the decomposition of hydrogen peroxides and subsequent production of reactive oxygen species. These discoveries were reported in the peer-reviewed journals, conference presentations, and outreach activities to the public.

This project has also impacted other disciplines by increasing the understanding of controlled-production of reactive oxygen species for potential applications that include functionalization of organic chemicals, break-down of organic pollutants in waste-water treatment, and utilization of reducible metal oxide nanoparticles for biomedical applications. Furthermore, the ozone-mediated synthetic methods developed in this project are versatile and they are applicable to synthesize other reducible transition metal oxide nanoparticle systems.

In addition, the project provided opportunities for research, teaching, and mentoring in the science and engineering areas for the future STEM workforce. The PI/Co-PI and their team provided STEM training for high school students, undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and visiting scholars. Two high school student researchers (one female and one male), five undergraduate researchers (two females and three males), and six graduate students (four females and two males) were trained in the morphology-control synthesis, structural characterization, and catalytic study of various transition metal oxide nanostructured catalysts. Two postdoctoral scholars (one female and one male) were trained in computation modeling of catalysis under this project. One of them accepted an academic position at a university. The research team also established international collaborations with scholars from China, Jordan, and Taiwan on the modeling study of proposed catalyst systems. These collaborations increased the exposure of the international team-working environment to students and postdoctoral scholars. Besides research, these students and postdoctoral scholars were also coached on scientific communications through manuscript-writing and conference presentations. Lastly, the PI/Co-PI and their team had also increased the awareness of catalysis science and nanoscience to the general public through outreach activities. Their participation in outreach activities such as the Nano Day exhibitions in the Gateway Mall (Lincoln Nebraska), Culler Middle School After School Nanoscience Program (Lincoln, Nebraska), Bright Lights Summer Nanocamps, and UNO Physics Open House provided exposure of nanoscience and technology to the general public.


Last Modified: 12/24/2018
Modified by: Chin Li Cheung

Their participation in outreach activities such as the Nano Day exhibitions in the Gateway Mall (Lincoln Nebraska), Culler Middle School After School Nanoscience Program (Lincoln, Nebraska), Bright Lights Summer Nanocamps, and UNO Physics Open House provided exposure of nanoscience and technology to the general public.
